causes: Italy's desire for territorial expansion and colonial acquisition
Ottoman Empire's weakened hold on its North African territories
Growing Italian nationalist sentiment and desire to establish an empire
Economic and strategic interests in the Mediterranean region
events_leading_up_to_war: Italy’s diplomatic efforts to pressure the Ottoman Empire to cede Libya fail
Italy presents an ultimatum to the Ottoman Empire, demanding the peaceful transfer of Libya
On 29 September 1911, Italy declares war on the Ottoman Empire and begins its invasion of Libya

territorial_changes: Ottoman Empire formally cedes control of Libya to Italy
Italy establishes control over Tripolitania and Cyrenaica, later unified as Libya

Kingdom_of_Italy.naval_power: Superior naval fleet with modern warships

Ottoman_Empire.naval_power: Lesser naval power compared to Italy, though still with strategic coastal forces
Ottoman_Empire.artillery: Outdated and insufficient for modern warfare

major_battles.name: Battle of Ain Zara
major_battles.description: An early Italian victory in the war, where Italian forces captured an important Ottoman position outside Tripoli.

major_battles.name: Battle of Tobruk
major_battles.description: Italian forces successfully defeated Ottoman defenders in Cyrenaica, gaining control over key coastal towns.

major_battles.name: Siege of Tripoli
major_battles.description: A prolonged siege by Italian forces that led to the capture of Tripoli, marking a decisive victory in the war.

terms: The Ottoman Empire cedes control of Libya to Italy
Italy gains sovereignty over all of Libya, which includes the provinces of Tripolitania and Cyrenaica
Ottoman Empire retains nominal authority over the city of Fezzan, but Italy soon extends control
impact: Libya becomes a full-fledged colony of Italy
This marks the beginning of Italy’s formal colonial empire in North Africa

long_term_effects: Libya remains under Italian control until World War II, with resistance from local populations continuing throughout
The war marks a significant moment in the decline of the Ottoman Empire’s ability to hold onto its remaining North African territories

economic: Italy's acquisition of Libya opens the door to increased exploitation of its resources, particularly oil and agricultural land
The acquisition of Libya contributes to Italy's increased global influence, though it remains an underdeveloped colony compared to France's or Britain’s possessions
political: The war leads to greater nationalist sentiment in Italy, fueling the rise of fascism and imperial ambitions in the following decades
The weakening of the Ottoman Empire accelerates its loss of power in North Africa and the Middle East
social: The war leads to increased Italian settlement in Libya and a significant number of Italian expatriates moving to the colony
Libya experiences internal tensions and revolts as local populations resist foreign occupation
